passages.text: As part of our routine post- quarter housekeeping, we update our models for Elm, Solutions, e&, Mobily and stc.

Elm (Buy) - Decrease PT to SAR1,220 (from SAR1,415): Our 2025/27E revenue decreases by \(3\% /9\%\) or by \(2\% /7\%\) ex- Thiqah, mainly to account for the softer 2Q, specifically BPO (which we cut by \(4\% /21\%\) on organic basis) and Thiqah (which we cut by \(16 - 18\%\) ) while digital segment cuts are limited \((2\% /3\%\) on organic basis). As we also incorporate stronger profitability, we lift 2025/27E EBIT margin by \(50 / 30bp\) (or \(140bp / 10bp\) on an organic basis) limiting consolidated adjusted EPS revisions to \(- 1.7\%\) for 2025- 27E (reported EPS \(+3\%\) for 2025E and \(- 6.8\%\) for 2026- 27E). Our model now implies that the Thiqah deal brings \(3.5\%\) EPS dilution in 2025E, \(6.1\%\) accretion in 2026E and \(10.4\%\) accretion in 2027E.

Solutions (Buy) - Decrease PT to SAR330 (from SAR350): Our 2025/27E revenue decreases by \(1\% /2\%\) to account for the weaker 2Q (we cut core ICT segment by \(1\% /2\%\) ) and more distant impact of smart parking projects (we cut digital segment by \(6\% /6\%\) ), while IT managed and operational services segment remains largely intact. This results in adjusted EPS revisions of \(- 1\% / - 3\%\) for 2025/27E (reported EPS intact for 2025E and \(- 1 - 2\%\) for 2026- 27E).

e& (Buy) - Increase PT to AED21.0 (from AED20.0): Our 2025/27E revenue increases by \(3\% /4\%\) on the back of strong 2Q and FX (EUR and MAD) mainly to reflect higher estimates for MT, Egypt, PPF and e& enterprise. As we also incorporate lower EBITDA margin (+10bp in 2025E, - 30bp in 2026E, - 80bp in 2027E) to reflect the revenue mix shift in the UAE and higher competition for Careem (through higher losses for e& life) our adjusted EPS revisions are limited for 2025- 26E, but we raise 2027E by \(3\%\) .

Mobily (Buy) - Increase PT to SAR75.0 (from SAR74.0): Our 2025/27E revenue is broadly intact as lower B2B estimates \((- 4\% / - 7\%)\) are offset by higher wholesale \((+3\% / + 5\%)\) . We only slightly revise EBITDA margin (+10bp in 2025- 27E) but also incorporate higher income from associates and JVs and higher finance costs that drives adjusted EPS revisions of \(0\% / - 2\%\) (similar changes to reported EPS). Our 2025- 27E DPS is intact, at SAR2.80/3.30/3.80, implying \(65\% /68\% /70\%\) payout in 2025- 27E.

stc (Hold) - Maintain PT at SAR46.0: Our 2025/27E revenue is \(- 1\%\) as we lower EBU estimates by \(4 - 6\%\) . We raise EBITDA margin by \(20 - 70bp\) (to capture stronger 1H performance) that limits our adjusted EBITDA revisions to \(0\% /1\%\) , while our adjusted EPS for 2026/27E is broadly intact (2025E is \(- 3\%\) ; but \(+2\%\) on reported basis).
KEY STOCKS FEATURED INCLUDE:

Investment Thesis / Where We Differ
We rate Elm Buy for 3 reasons:

(1) c.18% organic revenue growth to in 2025-27E; we highlight that even the most mature product Absher has shown 95% growth in transactions in 2024 and automated operations were \(+72\%\) Y/Y in Jan-Jul 2025;

(2) Consolidation of Thiaghi is dilutive in 2025E (-3.5%) but turns accretive from 2026E (we factor in 6.1%/10.4% positive impact on EPS for 2025-27E); the announced SAR200-300m mid-term Thiaghi cost synergies are not yet fully in our model and would present further upside.
(3) The stock is on 25x 2026E P/E, 12m forward P/E of 26x is \(>25\%\) below all-time average. With \(>40\%\) upside to our new PT we find risk-reward appealing.
Risk/Reward - 12 Month View
Base Case, SAR1220, \(+42\%\)

The stock re-rates to 34.8x 2026 P/E. Assumptions: 2026 EPS of SAR35.1, based on: (1) 19.5% Y/Y standalone product revenue growth; (2) 15.0% Y/Y standalone BPO revenue growth; (3) 13.6% Thiaghi LFL revenue growth; (4) 23.1% EBIT margin
Upside Scenario, SAR1309, \(+53\%\)
The stock re-rates to 35.0x 2026 P/E.

Assumptions: 2026 EPS of SAR37.4, based on: (1) 22.0% Y/Y standalone product revenue growth; (2) 20.0% Y/Y standalone BPO revenue growth; (3) 20.0% Thiaghi LFL revenue growth driven by fast- tracked implementation of value-added services and cross-selling; (4) 24.0% EBIT margin reflecting high operating leverage and bigger than expected cost optimisation at Thiaghi.
Downside Scenario, SAR723, - 16%
The stock de-rates to 23.0x 2026 P/E.

Assumptions: 2026 EPS of SAR31.4, based on: (1) 12.0% Y/Y standalone product revenue growth; (2) 5.0% Y/Y standalone BPO revenue growth; (3) 5.0% Thiaghi LFL revenue growth driven by slower implementation of value-added services and cross-selling; (4) 22.0% EBIT margin reflecting lower than expected cost optimisation at Thiaghi.

Elm published its first sustainability report in 2023. The company operates a sustainability framework that is aligned with Vision 2030 and the UN SDGs. The 4 pillars include: effective governance, enabling a digital culture, fostering people and the community and advancing environmental responsibility. Through strategic partnerships, ELM has introduced AI solutions, helping to drive down emissions in the transportation sector, reducing the carbon footprint, as well as other efforts towards waste reduction and resource optimisation. Elm's support of inclusivity, diversity and women's empowerment continues, with female employees representing 41% of the total as of FY23 and young talent aged 18- 30 years representing 36%. 73% of Elm's suppliers are also local. The company's risk management process incorporates ESG risks, with particular emphasis on environmental risks. The main focus remains on using digitization to implement sustainable practices across all firm operations.
Beginning of Nov - 3Q25 results (tbc)
SAR2025E2026E2027EFY P/Adj EPS30.0x24.5x19.7xFY P/E30.0x25.2x20.2xEV/EBITDA26.9x21.4x17.8x
We see four reasons to buy the stock:

(1) \(10\% +\) growth from 2H25 is achievable. Multiple growth drivers including managed and operational services, Giza and PPP (Public-private partnerships). In particular, the Riyadh Smart parking project; the Sports Boulevard contract will kick off in 1Q26; growing % or revenue sharing, i.e. recurring revenue, should help lift the valuation multiple; 
(2) \(>15\%\) EBITDA margins to sustain 
(3) FCF generation to further improve, we expect more M&A in 2025-26. 
(4) Solutions is on \(17\times 12m\) forward P/E, c. \(30\%\) below its all-time average. Our new 2026 FCFE implies \(5.8\%\) yield which is appealing in a global IT context.
Risk/Reward - 12 Month View

The stock re-rates to 22.1x 2026 P/E. Assumptions: 2026 EPS of SAR14.9, based on: (1) \(6.5\%\) Y/Y core ICT revenue growth; (2) \(17.0\%\) Y/Y digital revenue growth; (3) \(23.1\%\) gross profit margin.

The stock re-rates to 23.0x 2026 P/E. Assumptions: 2026 EPS of SAR16.2, based on: (1) \(9.0\%\) Y/Y core ICT revenue growth; (2) \(20.0\%\) Y/Y digital revenue growth driven by accelerated ramp-up of Riyadh Smart Parking project; (3) \(24.0\%\) gross profit margin achieved via better cost savings between Solutions, Giza and ccc.

The stock de-rates to 15.0x 2026 P/E. Assumptions: 2026 EPS of SAR14.5, based on: (1) \(3.0\%\) Y/Y core ICT revenue growth; (2) \(10.0\%\) Y/Y digital revenue growth driven by slower ramp-up of Riyadh Smart Parking project; (3) \(23.0\%\) gross profit margin driven by lower cost savings between Solutions, Giza and ccc.

Solutions published its second sustainability report in 2023. The GROW strategy was introduced in 2023, serving as a roadmap to promote transparent governance, to enhance social impact and to commit to eco-friendly operations. GROW comprises of four focus areas, namely - Greening by Sustainable Technologies and Processes, Revitalizing Workforce Relations and Digital Social Empowerment, Optimizing Governance for Ethical Excellence, and Widening Impactful Partnerships and Sustainable Procurement. The strategy is aligned with Vision 2030 goals and UNGC principles. Digital innovation helps achieve climate change efficiencies, especially through the Integrated Management System (IMS). Females represent \(19\%\) of the workforce and young people aged 18- 30 years represent \(25\%\) , supporting the company's diversity and inclusion efforts. STC has also developed a comprehensive Learning & Development strategy called 'Digital Future Talent' to upskill individuals, and continues to actively give back to the local community through digital advancements.
End of October - 3Q25 results (tbc)
SAR2025E2026E2027EFY P/Adj EPS18.3x16.2x14.1xFY P/E18.3x16.3x14.1xEV/EBITDA13.2x11.3x10.1x
We give four reasons to Buy the stock:
(1) As we see clear roadmap to enhance returns, we are more constructive on Marco Telecom, PPF and Mobily \((25\%)\) of our SOTP valuation combined).
(2) Our 2025-27E EBITDA is \(4 - 6\%\) above consensus.

(3) Valuation is attractive. e& trades on \(12.6\times 12m\) forward P/E, \(>15\%\) discount to the key MENA peer stc. Our reverse SOTP analysis suggests that the bestin-class UAE telco business is valued on 5x 2025E EV/EBITDA.
(4) c. \(5\%\) 2025-26E DY is accompanied by the AED8bn sale of Khazna (creating AED5bn value) and deleveraging to 1.2x (incl. leases) by the end of 2025E.
Risk/Reward - 12 Month View
The stock re-rates to a weighted average of \(4.5\%\) 2025 DY and 15.5x 2026 P/E.

(1) 2025 DPS of AED0.86 as per the dividend policy 
(2) 2026 EPS of AED1.48, based on 3pp Y/Y increase in the UAE mobile penetration; \(1.0\%\) Y/Y growth for UAE mobile ARPU: \(25.0\%\) EBITDA margin at e& life.
The stock re-rates to a weighted average of \(4.5\%\) 2025 DY and 16.0x 2026 P/E.
(1) 2025 DPS of AED1.00 on the back of faster deleveraging.
(2) 2026 EPS of AED1.51, based on 5pp Y/Y increase in the UAE mobile penetration; \(3.0\%\) Y/Y growth for UAE mobile ARPU: \(-15.0\%\) EBITDA margin at e& life.
The stock de-rates to a weighted average of \(5.5\%\) 2025 DY and 11.0x 2026 P/E.
(1) 2025 DPS of AED0.86 as per the dividend policy. \(5.5\%\) DY accounting for higher M&A/execution risks.

(2) 2026 EPS of AED1.44, based on 1pp Y/Y increase in the UAE mobile penetration; \(-1.0\%\) Y/Y growth for UAE mobile ARPU: \(-35.0\%\) EBITDA margin at e& life due to more intense competition in the MENA food delivery sector.

In 2023, e& created a Sustainability Committee to refresh the strategy and focus. e& acted as the Principal Technology Partner for COP28. e& built on its net zero (Scope 1 and 2) commitment by 2030 for its UAE operations and for the entire Group by 2040 through focus on modernising its network to improve efficiencies and progress towards renewable energy ambitions. The company is also committed to a \(25\%\) reduction in Scope 3 emissions by 2030. With regard to equity and inclusion, the company was a signatory to the UN Women Empowerment Principles, a new partnership focused on people with disabilities. Women represent \(c.26\%\) of the workforce. There continues to be a strong focus on talent attraction, retention and development (including local talent in line with Emiratisation efforts). e& also revamped its code of conduct to ensure the highest standards of ethics and integrity, including cybersecurity and data privacy.
End of October - 3Q25 results (tbc)
AED2025E2026E2027EFY P/E10.6x12.2x11.2xEV/EBITDA6.3x5.8x5.5xEV/Rev2.7x2.5x2.4xP/Rev2.2x2.0x1.9xFY P/Adj EPS13.2x12.2x11.2x
With "De- risked value compounder" thesis intact we reiterate our Buy post 2Q25.
(1) After \(42\%\) adjusted EPS growth in 2024, we forecast still solid \(13\%\) CAGR in 2024-27E, fuelled by \(7.0\%\) revenue CAGR.

(2) Even after marginally lifting capex, our FCFE forecasts imply solid \(>90\%\) conversion from Net income in 2026-27E. We project \(65\% /68\% /70\%\) dividend pay-out in 2025-27 (step-up from \(55\%\) in 2024). Still that implies, deleveraging to \(0.8x\) by the end of 2026E and \(0.6x\) by the end of 2027E posing further upside risks to DPS.
(3) On \(5.2\%\) '26E DY and \(13.1x\) '26E P/E we find risk-reward attractive.
(4) We see a catalyst in a 2H25 dividend recommendation (JEFe: SAR1.60). Our 2025-27E DPS is \(8 - 11\%\) above consensus.
Risk/Reward - 12 Month View
The stock re-rates to a weighted average of \(4.0\%\) 2025 DY and \(16.4x\) 2026 P/E.

(1) 2025 DPS of SAR2.80. 
(2) 2026 EPS of SAR4.89, based on 2pp Y/Y increase in the Saudi mobile penetration; \(11.0\%\) Y/Y growth in B2B: \(53.6\%\) gross profit margin.
The stock re-rates to a weighted average of \(4.0\%\) 2025 DY and \(16.5x\) 2026 P/E.
(1) 2025 DPS of SAR3.00, due to faster than expected deleveraging.
(2) 2026 EPS of SAR5.12, based on 4pp Y/Y increase in the Saudi mobile penetration; \(15.0\%\) Y/Y growth in B2B: \(54.0\%\) gross profit margin.
The stock de-rates to a weighted average of \(5.0\%\) 2025 DY and \(13.0x\) 2026 P/E.
(1) 2025 DPS of SAR2.40, due to slower than expected deleveraging.
(2) 2026 EPS of SAR4.43, based on 0pp Y/Y increase in the Saudi mobile penetration; \(5.0\%\) Y/Y growth in B2B: \(52.5\%\) gross profit margin.

Mobility implements 5 strategic pillars to achieve its ESG goals; (1) Accountable Enterprise: robust commitment to transparency and ethical practices through a comprehensive compliance programme. (2) Social marketplace and Customers: advanced tech and solutions to enhance customer experiences. Strides in the fintech space are enhancing financial literacy in KSA. There is also a focus on improving cybersecurity for the company through the 'RESILIENT' strategy. (3) Responsible Employer: fostering a diverse and dynamic corporate culture and training workers. (4) Positive Community Impacts: initiatives to give back to the Saudi society. The CSR strategy focuses on enriching the talent pool and enabling societal growth, for instance, sponsoring the Biban 23 Forum, to encourage SME growth. (5) Safeguarding the Planet: commitment to reducing its ecological footprint, including innovative energy solutions and the launch of the Mobily recycling initiative.
End of October - 3Q25 results (tbc)
SAR2025E2026E2027EFY P/E14.9x13.1x11.7xEV/EBITDA7.5x6.9x6.6xEV/Rev2.8x2.6x2.5xP/Rev2.5x2.3x2.2xFY P/Adj EPS14.9x13.1x11.7x
Investment Thesis / Where We Differ

(1) Operational trends remained mixed: including EBU growth and EBITDA margins. We do factor in the benefits of the accelerated voluntary leave program, but upside might be distant (we are in line with consensus on 2025 EBITDA and EPS).

(2) 4Q24 special dividend of SAR10bn was ahead of most expectations however given that FCFE will likely remain below basic dividend in 2025-27E, the market will need comfort on two matters before it starts factoring in special dividends on a recurring basis: (a) M&A; (b) working capital trends;
(3) Valuation. On 15.0x 12m fwd P/E stc is \(>10\%\) above e& and Mobily.
Risk/Reward - 12 Month View
Base Case, SAR46, \(+10\%\)
The stock re-rates to a weighted average of \(4.5\%\) 2025 DY and 14.8x 2026 P/E.
(1) 2025 DPS of SAR2.20, in line with the new dividend policy; no special dividend.
(2) 2026 EPS of SAR2.91, based on 2pp Y/Y increase in the Saudi mobile penetration; \(3.8\%\) Y/Y growth at EBU: \(61.5\%\) gross profit margin at stc KSA.
Upside Scenario, SAR52.8, \(+26\%\)
The stock re-rates to a weighted average of \(5.5\%\) 2025 DY and 15.5x 2026 P/E.
(1) 2025 DPS of SAR3.20. That assumes SAR2.20 DPS under the new dividend policy plus SAR1.00 special DPS supported by stronger cash generation including more favourable working capital.
(2) 2026 EPS of SAR3.05, based on 4pp Y/Y increase in the Saudi mobile penetration; \(7.0\%\) Y/Y growth at EBU: \(63.0\%\) gross profit margin at stc KSA achieved via bigger cost savings.
Downside Scenario, SAR39.3, \(- 6\%\)
The stock de-rates to a weighted average of \(5.0\%\) 2025 DY and 13.0x 2026 P/E.
(1) 2025 DPS of SAR2.20, in line with the new dividend policy; no special dividend.

(2) 2026 EPS of SAR2.66, based on 0pp Y/Y increase in the Saudi mobile penetration; \(0.0\%\) Y/Y growth at EBU due to continued pressure from de-monopolization in the B2G segment: \(60.0\%\) gross profit margin at stc KSA.

stc published its fifth sustainability report in 2023. The new ESG strategy is focused on three core sustainability priority areas: Environmental Performance and Climate, Development of Human Capital through Technological Innovation, and Solid Governance and Ethical Excellence. Digital innovation is a key facilitator of ESG for the company. The Group's environmental efforts have been formally recognized through the Forbes Middle East Sustainability Leaders Award, highlighting the commitment to reducing carbon emissions and promoting sustainable practices in climate, society, digitalization, and the future of work across KSA, Bahrain, and Kuwait. The company is a leading employer in the Gulf region with c.23k employees with females representing c.14% as of FY23. stc aims to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050. The company also introduced an ESG lens into the risk management framework and has also established a climate change strategy focused on science-based KPIs.
End of October - 3Q25 results (tbc)
TMTEquity ResearchAugust 28, 2025
SAR2025E2026E2027EFY P/E15.0x14.6x13.0xEV/EBITDA8.1x7.5x6.8xEV/Rev2.6x2.4x2.3xP/Rev2.7x2.5x2.3xFY P/Adj EPS16.0x14.5x12.9x

e&e& engages in the provision of telecommunication services, media and related equipment. e& operates in 16 countries across MENA while recently it have also gained exposure to Europe via investments in Vodafone and PPF Telecom. The company was founded on January 1, 1976 and is headquartered in Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates.

Etiad Etisalat Co. (Mobily) engages in the provision of mobile telecommunications service and related products. Its products include voice plans, internet solutions, handset devices, and digital stores. The firm also provides global positioning system, calls and videos, messaging, credit, multi subscriber identity module, and roaming services. The company was founded on August 18, 2004 and is headquartered in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia
Elm Co. provides integrated digital solutions and e- government services. The company was founded in 1986 and is headquartered in Riyadh, Kingdom of Saudi Arabia.

Solutions by stcEngages in the provision of information technology consulting and systems integration services. It operates through the following segments: Core ICT Services, IT Managed and Operational Services, and Digital Services. The company was founded on January 11, 2003 and is headquartered in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia.

stcEngages in the provision of telecommunication services, media and related equipment. stc is the market leader in Saudi Arabia while it also operates in Kuwait, Bahrain and Malaysia. Besides, recently it have also gained exposure to Europe via investments in Telefonica and United Group. The company was established on April 21, 1998 and is headquartered in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia.

We derive our AED21.0 PT based on a 50- 50 mix of a DCF- based SOTP and target 2025E DY of \(4.5\%\) . We use a DCF model to value UAE/Maroc Telecom/Egypt/Pakistan/PPF. Our key assumptions for the UAE include: (1) \(1.5\%\) PGR, (2) \(51.0\%\) terminal EBITDA margin, (3) \(9.5\%\) terminal capex/ revenue. (4) \(8.0\%\) WACC. We use current market price to calculate value of a \(16.1\%\) stake in Vodafone. We use a DCF- based fair valuation to calculate value of a \(28.0\%\) stake in Mobily. We value e& enterprise based on 13.0x 2026E EV/EBITDA. We value Starzplay, Careem, Wio, Newberry based on transaction values (Jefferies calculations). We apply a \(5\%\) target discount related to M&A risks. Key downside risks include: (1) weaker than expected UAE macro, reliant on oil prices, (2) FX devaluation across the footprint, (3) higher for longer losses at e& life, (4) M&A- related and execution risks.

We derive our SAR75.0 PT based on a 50- 50 mix of a DCF and target 2025E DY of \(4.0\%\) . Our key assumptions include: (1) \(1.5\%\) PGR, (2) \(37.0\%\) terminal EBITDA margin, (3) \(15.5\%\) terminal capex/revenue. (4) \(9.1\%\) WACC. Key downside risks include: (1) weaker- than- expected KSA macro, reliant on oil prices, (2) higher competition in B2B pressuring growth and margins, (3) slower than expected deleveraging curbing DPS growth.

We derive our SAR1,220 PT based on a DCF model. Our key assumptions include: (1) \(5.0\%\) PGR, (2) \(28.0\%\) terminal EBITDA margin, (3) \(1.0\%\) terminal capex/revenue, (4) \(9.5\%\) WACC. Key downside risks include: (1) weaker- than- expected Saudi macro, reliant on oil prices, (2) slower- than- anticipated digitalization of the Saudi public services, weighing on product revenue, (3) intensifying competition in the BPO segment, (4) tech talent scarcity and elevated attrition affecting margins, (5) FCF pressure from unfavourable working capital dynamics (namely delays in collection of government receivables), (6) M&A and execution risks including related to the Thiqah deal.

We derive our SAR330 PT based on a DCF model. Our key assumptions include: (1) \(3.5\%\) PGR, (2) \(16.5\%\) terminal EBITDA margin, (3) \(1.5\%\) terminal capex/revenue, and (4) \(9.7\%\) WACC. We use transaction valuation to calculate value of a \(40\%\) stake in Devoteam Middle East. Key downside risks include: (1) weaker- than- expected Saudi macro, reliant on oil prices, (2) intensifying competition in the Saudi IT, including with global players; (3) limited

diversification from stc and legacy services curbing growth potential amidst workloads transition to the cloud; (4) tech talent scarcity and elevated attrition affecting margins; (5) FCF pressure from unfavourable working capital dynamics; (6) M&A- related execution risks.

We derive our SAR46.0 PT based on a 50- 50 mix of a DCF and target 2025E DY of \(4.5\%\) . Our key assumptions include: (1) \(2.0\%\) PGR, (2) \(33.5\%\) terminal EBITDA margin, (3) \(15.0\%\) terminal capex/revenue, (4) \(8.9\%\) WACC. We use a DCF- based fair valuation to calculate value of a minority interest in Solutions. We use transaction values and our 2025E net debt estimate to calculate value of a minority interest in a new TowerCo. We use current market price to calculate value of a minority interest in stc Kuwait and a \(10.0\%\) stake in Telefonica. We apply a \(5\%\) target discount related to M&A/ execution risks. Key downside risks include: (1) weaker than expected KSA macro, reliant on oil prices, (2) bigger than expected pressure at stc EBU, (3) higher for longer losses at new verticals, (4) M&A- related and execution risks.
(Article 3(1)e and Article 7 of MAR) Recommendation Published Recommendation Distributed

Buy - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of \(15\%\) or more within a 12- month period. Hold - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of plus \(15\%\) or minus \(10\%\) within a 12- month period. Underperform - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of minus \(10\%\) or less within a 12- month period. The expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) for Buy rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) is \(20\%\) or more within a 12- month period as these companies are typically more volatile than the overall stock market. For Hold rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is plus or minus \(20\%\) within a 12- month period. For Underperform rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is minus \(20\%\) or less within a 12- month period. NR - The investment rating and price target have been temporarily suspended. Such suspensions are in compliance with applicable regulations and/or Jefferies policies.
CS - Coverage Suspended. Jefferies has suspended coverage of this company.
NC - Not covered. Jefferies does not cover this company.

Restricted - Describes issuers where, in conjunction with Jefferies engagement in certain transactions, company policy or applicable securities regulations prohibit certain types of communications, including investment recommendations.
Monitor - Describes securities whose company fundamentals and financials are being monitored, and for which no financial projections or opinions on the investment merits of the company are provided.

Jefferies methodology for assigning ratings may include the following: market capitalization, maturity, growth/value, volatility and expected total return over the next 12 months. The price targets are based on several methodologies, which may include, but are not restricted to, analyses of market risk, growth rate, revenue stream, discounted cash flow (DCF), EBITDA, EPS, cash flow (CF), free cash flow (FCF), EV/EBITDA, P/E, PE/growth, P/CF, P/FCF, premium (discount)/average group EV/EBITDA, premium (discount)/average group P/E, sum of the parts, net asset value, dividend returns, and return on equity (ROE) over the next 12 months.

Jefferies Franchise Picks include stock selections from among the best stock ideas from our equity analysts over a 12 month period. Stock selection is based on fundamental analysis and may take into account other factors such as analyst conviction, differentiated analysis, a favorable risk/reward ratio and investment themes that Jefferies analysts are recommending. Jefferies Franchise Picks will include only Buy rated stocks and the number can vary depending on analyst recommendations for inclusion. Stocks will be added as new opportunities arise and removed when the reason for inclusion changes, the stock has met its desired return, if it is no longer rated Buy and/or if it triggers a stop loss. Stocks having 120 day volatility in the bottom quartile of S&P stocks will continue to have a 15% stop loss, and the remainder will have a 20% stop. Franchise Picks are not intended to represent a recommended portfolio of stocks and is not sector based, but we may note where we believe a Pick falls within an investment style such as growth or value.
